comments.text:
I like my Acer270, it's a tool/accessory, it was cheap ($150 tax+shipping). 
 To me re-watching this ad, what I like is it's a cute and optimistic spin 
on a "Friendly AI"...answering queries about a new paradigm.  (Even how the 
answers are all musical notes plucked with animations vs. spoken.  It 
captures the spirit of patience with someone with old ideas being shown new 
ones, like "wait?  why!  don't throw it in a river")

BUT: My praise is only as long as it's open source and not going to brick 
you for "watching the wrong video" or "having the wrong letter sequence in 
your name", or something 1984-like.  So please reassure me that Google is 
too big and color-coded to fail.  Let's not resort to calling up 
survivalists with their magnetic core memory...society hinging its premises 
upon coursonaggoni...﻿

comments.author: Mithilesh prajapati

comments.text:
+Don Yates I am not blaming the Chromebook devices, but the platform 
concept is mostly dependent on bandwidth, and today's bandwidth can't 
support audio or video editing in a practical manner IMHO. The result is 
the same though - you need a full blown computer to supplement your 
Chromebook if you have any of these needs. I see the Chromebook as a 
portability and price compromise for now. A good one, but a compromise 
never-the-less.
comments.author: Steve Liberty

comments.text:
+Steve Liberty What about bandwidth? I've loved my CB since I bought it, 
but since i've had to rely upon my 3G phone hotspot for the past 6 mths. or 
so, it's been a little trying. But on a good WiFi conn., it's gangbusters.
Your file transfer *performance* likely has nothing to do with local 
processing horsepower (HW or SW), IMHO. Of course, this doesn't rule out 
snags that are exclusive to Google Drive.
Or, did you already know this?
comments.author: Don Yates

comments.text:
+Peter Doesburg Agreed, it will get better. But until I can transfer a 1/2 
GB file in 15 seconds to the cloud, I'll always want/need a powerful 
machine somewhere o do these tasks without shipping my data up and back. 
Maybe a desktop, or maybe my laptop will have to have the power (if/when I 
give up on desktops).

Since I am a Chromebook user, I am obviously onboard with the benefits of 
the cloud, and ultra-portability. It just hasn't reached the level where I 
can dump the desktop yet. I long for that day to come soon.

Really, all I need is a 2.5gHz i5 with 8GB of RAM and an SSD in an ultra 
form factor for $300, and I will be very happy. Is that so much to ask? :)
comments.author: Steve Liberty

comments.text:
Audio and video editing is indeed not optimal yet +Steve Liberty​, but 
"light" editing work can be done fairly well. Obviously its no match to 
full fledged editing suites, but thats onky a very small % of the market.
The new macbook is clearly following the chromebook trend of moving 
everythig away from powerful hardware and into the cloud, so serbivices 
will only get better and so do internet speeds for that matter
comments.author: Peter Doesburg

comments.text:
"You can do everything on the web" - well, no, you can't. I do love my 
Chromebook, but this claim is just not true. Some things are totally 
impractical on the web, and probably always will be. Like audio and video 
editing. I record my band, and later cut up and EQ the individual songs. 
With a source file of nearly 500MB, editing this file on the web makes no 
sense. it is just too slow to upload the entire file, and the download the 
individual slices. And thats just audio. Video would be even worse. But you 
can do MOST things on the web. I'd agree with that.
comments.author: Steve Liberty

comments.text:
كثير منا لا يعرف الكروم بوك (Chromebook)هو جهاز كمبيوتر شخصي *لابتوب* يعمل 
بنظام قوقل كروم كنظام تشغيل أساسي. وقد صممت هذه الأجهزة لاستخدامها أثناء 
الاتصال بالإنترنت ودعم التطبيقات الموجودة على شبكة الإنترنت. وقد طورت قوقل 
و مطورين البرامج بعض التطبيقات التي ممكن ان تعمل دون الإتصال بالانترنت.. 
وحتى شركة مايكروسوفت دعمت اهم تطبيقاتها المكتبية مثل الوورد والاكسل 
والبوربوينت على هذا النظام. 

يصلح هذا النظام لمن هم مثلي ٩٩٪ من استخدامي للابتوب سواء للترفيه او العمل 
يكون في الانترنت. سريع جدا في آدائه وتشغيله لا يأخذ سوى 3 ثواني وتكون جاهز 
للاستخدام.. الفيديو يوضح الفكرة بشكل مختصر وجميل..

comments.text:
I purchased a Chromebook. Salesman said you really can't do a lot with it 
because you can't install drivers, for example print. I thought there has 
to be a way. I get it home and start playing with it. Using Google Cloud 
Print you can print. The more exposure to the Google Ecosystem I have the 
more impressed I am with it. Not only can I print and use programs but I 
can do nearly anything I would on my other computers. Keeping in mind I am 
not a gamer. With cloud print I can also share my printer with other people 
regardless of where they are. The more i use this the more impressed I am. 
Its also very fast. Like the video says no waiting to get online after 
powering up.﻿

comments.author: Heidi Fischer

comments.text:
I am currently using Chromebook Acer C720. My home was 4 laptops; macboook 
pro [1200$, 4 years ago], Microsoft [600$, 1 year ago], and 2 Chromebook 
(64$ each, 6 months ago) . And so far this is my favorite, cheaper too.

I got it for about 64$ including all that shipping and stuff. it was a 
Amazon Kindle offer, had 5000 in stock. Lucky me cause i think original 
price was 200$

It works really well. to be honest i dropped it 3 times on cement floor at 
height of 1 foot [from bed] and it still works. also spilled coffee... and 
soda... Sorry Laptop. :'(

Its convenient too like the fact that a google account is the center, since 
i can be logged in to youtube as well. Also since its based on google 
accounts, no one ever has to come to my account. Like on the other laptop 
my i mentioned [my brother's], he has his own google account so when he 
like screen locks it i cant go in. But if i just log out and log in on my 
account i could go in but its my account and not his.
Oh and a down side is that i cant download torrents, so what i do is 
download on mac, then usb, then watch it here. 

To sum it up, good laptop. Never thought that i'd be saying this 
but...(inhale) its better than my MacBook Pro from apple. Bye Bye apple, 
its just the new update sucks.

- Diana﻿

comments.author: Rungtip Kantawong

comments.text:
Well, I've been having some problems with my wireless Internet connection. 
Instead of unplugging and plugging the router back in, I thought I'd reboot 
my chromebook, see if that helped. It didn't. Apparently, not only didn't 
it help the connection *but I need an Internet connection to sign in*. I 
thought chromebooks were supposed to have offline capabilities? Seems such 
things are only available in... guest mode? But then I wouldn't have access 
to any offline files. You know: that syncing thing for everything I upload 
that's been forced on me? Apparently it's freaking useless *unless I have 
an Internet connection*... in which case it's useless.

This happened after having rebooted earlier this morning for the most 
recent update to Chrome OS. Google, you have some weird ideas on computers. 
They're a lot weirder than your ads suggest.

#chromebook   #google   #chrome   #falseadvertising   #notoffline   #nope   
#fwp  ﻿
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+Pedro Martins Zamboni Well, I'm assuming I have no strong reason to 
distrust you and I've done a search for the names of the four people most 
responsible for Google and the Chromebook and omitted their names for the 
most part, but you are a stranger.

I've only quickly skimmed it, barely seeing anything at all. But perhaps it 
will give you some insight into what it's been like.

I'll share separately and privately as soon as I bring up Google+ (using a 
notifier in Google Maps now).
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+Pedro Martins Zamboni Actually, it's only 73 pages. I didn't mean to 
exaggerate, but I should have been more careful. I'm so used to the 
document taking such a long time to load that I don't want to open it 
unless it's really necessary. And because I primarily use this 6- to 
7-year-old computer now, I have far fewer compulsions to complain about a 
machine I basically use when I watch videos in bed or to listen to music 
since I don't have external speakers for the desktop.
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+Pedro Martins Zamboni I may be willing to share it, but truth be told, 
there's stuff in there, curses against those most responsible for the 
Chromebook, Chrome OS, and Google, that I'd rather not share. Perhaps I 
will share some of it by making a copy, quickly deleting anything I think 
is too much to share, then pasting it into a privately shared message on 
Google+.
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+Timothy J. Holloway Maybe we should just stop this discussion... For many 
reasons I think our opinions are not going to change, and no matter what we 
say we will be simply wasting our times... Also, since, repeating once 
again, I never owned a chromebook, I do not have experience with them to 
make proper counter arguments.

But, just for curiosity, would you mind sharing that 80-pages reports you 
mentioned?
comments.author: Pedro Martins Zamboni (Zambonifofex)

comments.text:
+Pedro Martins Zamboni Again, maybe it isn't meant to do the stuff you want 
it to do, and that doesn't mean it is bad, it only means that it's just not 
the right computer for *you*, and that is not a reason to start complaining 
about "how Google cannot handle their O.S. with competence"... If you had a 
bad time with the thing, them simply quit using it, but understand that it 
doesn't necessarily means it's bad.﻿

... I've used this machine for 3 years. I'm actually on a desktop computer 
from 2008 which has a processor that is about 3 times the speed of the 
Intel Atom processor in the 2011 chromebook, according to figures on 
PassMark.com.

As you've said repeatedly, you don't have one, don't use one. You don't 
really know what you're talking about. At the beginning of 2013, I started 
documenting my complaints about this chromebook. It's 80 pages long now. 
Some of it is longer rants but most of it is entries of a few lines on 
problems and repeated problems with the interface, wireless, Google Drive, 
boots, logins, tabs automatically refreshing, being told Chrome OS would 
start automatically deleting files because Offline, which I couldn't 
disable (even though I had "disabled" it via Google Drive, it had no 
effect), was taking up the lion's share of the 16GB SSD, and many other 
things.

You don't know. Coming onto this thread and suggesting to me very obvious 
stuff that makes me out to be a bit simple-minded actually makes you look 
simple-minded to me. People like you are why the chromebook is successful. 
You make good slaves. You work crappy jobs or maybe not-so-crappy jobs that 
used to pay well but really give you enough that you can afford to blow 
most of it on over-priced stuff the cost of which has become dirt-cheap to 
producers because they've ensured as the super-rich that everyone else is 
working for nothing while they make all the money, whether average citizens 
are working for minimum wage, or are lawyers, doctors, or even business 
people running relatively large businesses that are nothing compared to the 
truly big and successful businesses.

But that's still no excuse for not checking it out for yourself before 
coming onto my post and suggesting I'm the one responsible for my bad 
experience. It is my fault for trusting Google to keep or try to keep its 
promises, but my goal, when I get around to it, will be to help others not 
to make the same mistake in thinking Google has their best interests at 
heart or will honour the ethos of "Don't Be Evil" when they'd happily screw 
you over if they knew, based on their organized information, that they 
could easily get away with it because people like *you* will let them.

Here's another ad from Google: http://youtu.be/0QRO3gKj3qw

If you're not willing to exercise more than the kind of entry-level 
mentality that a modern 14-year-old could easily exceed when it comes to 
technology and choosing appropriate devices, I don't think you have any 
right to expect me to treat you any better, and I prefer not to associate 
with minors.
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+Pedro Martins Zamboni  Considering that there aren't many people with 
complaints about Chrome O.S., that seems to be the case. If it indeed did 
not met Google promises, you would see a lot more people complaining.

... Most people are morons or lack integrity, hence the condition of the 
world and them merely bitching about the government in a democracy instead 
of clearly showing whether they're being represented or not and 
unceremoniously kicking out posers who insist on fucking them over.
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+Pedro Martins Zamboni Maybe you simply have set expectations to the 
chromebook that simply weren't true, and got frustrated as it didn't met 
them.

... Google made promises that it broke when it didn't have to. It would 
have cost them more money in writing better code to keep those promises, 
but they basically screwed over early adopters that counted on their 
promises of "Fast Web" or "Fast. Web..." and anything else they said. I 
think Google knew that people like you would gloss over what's happened 
instead of paying attention and even make excuses for Google because the 
very Windows computers and Windows operating system Google criticized in 
promoting the chromebook is still your standard and you simply see 
chromebooks and Chrome OS as browser-only computers. Google is in full 
control of the operating system and has maybe two dozen models of 
chromebooks and chromeboxes to keep up with... unlike Android, which Google 
is also responsible for, and which runs many apps that run directly on the 
operating system, as opposed to within the browser. Compared to Android, 
Chrome OS is extremely simplistic, running mostly conventional hardware, 
but with specialized firmware, boot, desktop environment (which was their 
choice), a web browser, and a file manager.

My expectations were based directly on what Google promised instead of the 
experiences with more-conventional computers that Google said chrome 
notebooks would be different from.
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+Pedro Martins Zamboni They are not made to handle complex tasks, but 
rather to display and run lightweight web pages and web apps.

Let me show you something else from Google, from Nov 19, 2009: 
http://youtu.be/ANMrzw7JFzA

Consider that this was a demo. The finished product should have been of 
higher or "finished" quality. What they released was a very much 
stripped-down version until they changed the desktop interface to Aura, 
breaking their promises or stated plans and SLOWING things down. The boot 
speed (BOOT SPEED) has gotten much slower, and that doesn't make any sense 
since the only things being added to the boot are Google's code, which 
unless something has become so useful as to double the boot speed, it's 
really just Google's bloated code.
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+Pedro Martins Zamboni Chrome O.S., as any O.S., tend to get slower with 
time, since new features get added, however, normally, hardware gets 
updated as well to accommodate the software changes. Maybe your computer is 
just getting a little old, and not being able to handle the newer versions 
of the O.S. that are made with newer hardware in mind.

... Here's another ad from Google which I have posted many times:

comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+Timothy J. Holloway You seem to be the only person that is having a 
legitimate problem with Chrome O.S. (by legitimate I mean that it isn't 
just *"This thing is dumb, I can't even play Minecraft, and it only have 
16GB of HDD, it sucks..."*). I myself do not own a chromebook, so I can't 
say much, but have you ever considered that it just might not be the right 
machine for you?

Chromebooks are mainly made to be used online, they don't really put much 
effort and attention to the file explorer, so little bugs might remain 
unnoticed for an extended period of time, but saying they "beta test things 
on users" is just a flat lie, considering that chrome/chrome O.S. features 
have to pass through 3 different channels before getting released on the 
regular channel. (Canary, Dev, Beta, and regular). If you do have an issue, 
see if it's not mentioned here: 
https://support.google.com/chromebook/known-issues and if it is not, do 
report it.

Chrome O.S., as any O.S., tend to get slower with time, since new features 
get added, however, normally, hardware gets updated as well to accommodate 
the software changes. Maybe your computer is just getting a little old, and 
not being able to handle the newer versions of the O.S. that are made with 
newer hardware in mind. Again, as I never had a chromebook I cannot say for 
sure, but I do believe chromebooks are generally slower than regular 
computers, but they are much cheaper as well... They are not made to handle 
complex tasks, but rather to display and run lightweight web pages and web 
apps.

Maybe you simply have set expectations to the chromebook that simply 
weren't true, and got frustrated as it didn't met them. Considering that 
there aren't many people with complaints about Chrome O.S., that seems to 
be the case. If it indeed did not met Google promises, you would see a lot 
more people complaining. Again, maybe it isn't meant to do the stuff you 
want it to do, and that doesn't mean it is bad, it only means that it's 
just not the right computer for *you*, and that is not a reason to start 
complaining about "how Google cannot handle their O.S. with competence"... 
If you had a bad time with the thing, them simply quit using it, but 
understand that it doesn't necessarily means it's bad.
comments.author: Pedro Martins Zamboni (Zambonifofex)
